required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Lubricating Gel on Patient Comfort During Speculum Insertion.
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Lubricating Gel on Patient Comfort During Speculum Insertion.

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine if lubricating gel affects patients' perception of discomfort during speculum insertion, as compared to water.

detailed_description.textblock: The outcome measure is patient discomfort as measured by a visual analogue scale.

primary_outcome.measure: Patient Discomfort During Speculum Insertion as Measured by a Visual Analog Scale.
primary_outcome.description: The outcome measure is a single measurement of pain using a 10-point visual analog scale entitled "Visual Pain Scale" immediately following speculum insertion. The scale is a continuous 10cm line with the minimum value of 0 (labeled "no pain") on the left side of the line, and a maximum value of 10 (labeled "worst pain") on the right side of the line. Higher scores represent more pain and a worse outcome. There are no additional measurements obtained, and patients will not be followed for study purposes thereafter.

intervention.intervention_name: Lubricating gel used during speculum insertion.
intervention.description: Examiner will use 0.5 mL of sterile lubricating gel to lubricate standard-sized plastic speculum during clinically indicated vaginal speculum examination. Patients will mark visual analog scale immediately following insertion.
Patients will under vaginal speculum examination using 3 mL of water as a lubricant and will mark a visual analog scale immediately after speculum insertion.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Women undergoing vaginal speculum examination between the ages of 18 and 50.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnancy.
- Non-English speaking.
- Using hormone therapy.
- Active vulvar or vaginal lesion, infection or complaint.
- Undergoing vaginal or vulvar procedure or biopsy.
- History of chronic pelvic pain, interstitial cystitis or vulvar vestibulitis.
- History of prior vulvar or vaginal surgical procedures.

facility.name: Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Florida Hospital

responsible_party.investigator_title: Associate Director, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
